comment: I feel like you deleted a video on the same topic, didn't you
I absolutely love the way you explain things! <33 Thankyou so much for all ur effort!

The problem is that no one is explaining why an object with a smaller density is floating, and an object with a higher density is sinking. And why does it sink in infinity? Can someone smart answer that?
God bless you brother! You're amazing, I appreciate your industry, and your heart in making these videos. Much love!

Basically, when an object has a low density, that means 1 of 2 things: 1. The object has a low mass. This means that the object will have a lower weight, and will thus need a smaller buoyant force to counteract it, thus making it easy for it to float.   2. The object has a high volume. In this case, if the same mass of the object were submerged in water, it would displace a larger amount of water, thus increasing the buoyant force acting upon the object (Archimedes Principle) and allowing it to float
